questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue and a cough productive of a blood-tinged phlegm. Over the past month, he has had a 5.0-kg (11-lb) weight loss. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Eight months ago, he underwent a kidney transplantation. The patient does not smoke. His current medications include lisinopril, insulin, prednisone, and mycophenolate mofetil. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.1°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. Rhonchi are heard at the right lower lobe of the lung on auscultation. There is a small ulceration on the left foot. An x-ray of the chest shows a right lung mass with lobar consolidation. Antibiotic therapy with levofloxacin is started. Three days later, the patient has a seizure and difficulty coordinating movements with his left hand. An MRI of the brain shows an intraparenchymal lesion with peripheral ring enhancement. Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage yields weakly acid-fast, gram-positive bacteria with branching, filamentous shapes. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol are antibiotics indicated in the treatment of tuberculosis. Posttransplant patients receiving immunosuppressive therapy are at increased risk of tuberculosis, which can manifest with similar pulmonary (lung mass with consolidation), extrapulmonary (cerebral abscess), and constitutional symptoms. Mycobacterium tuberculosis is, however, strongly acid-fast and not usually filamentous or branching.

B) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is commonly used to treat infections with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Infection with MRSA can cause a variety of pulmonary, skin, and CNS findings. However, the bacterium is not acid-fast and presents as a gram-positive coccus on Gram stain.

C) INCORRECT:

Piperacillin/tazobactam is used in the treatment of pneumonia caused by gram-negative bacilli such as Pseudomonas species. Pseudomonas pneumonia can occur in immunosuppressed patients but does not usually manifest with CNS and skin findings. Pseudomonas aeruginosa would appear as a gram-negative rather than a gram-positive aerobic rod on Gram stain.

D) CORRECT:

Long-term therapy (≥ 6 months) with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the treatment of choice for nocardiosis. In patients with CNS involvement, combination therapy with imipenem is indicated. Additionally, a neurosurgical consultation should be initiated for stereotactic aspiration or surgical excision of the brain abscess.

The lungs are the primary site of infection in most cases of nocardiosis. While pulmonary nocardiosis may occasionally occur in immunocompetent patients, disseminated disease is almost always associated with underlying immunosuppression, e.g., due to HIV infection, organ transplant, glucocorticoid therapy, recent chemotherapy, or diabetes mellitus.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of bacteria in blood culture (Kinyoun stain)

Clusters of branching, filamentous rods are concentrated in the center.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythromycin can be used to treat atypical pneumonia (e.g., due to infection with Chlamydia pneumoniae or Mycoplasma pneumoniae). Atypical pneumonia usually manifests with a low-grade fever and a non-productive cough; CNS and cutaneous involvement are uncommon. In addition, Mycoplasma pneumoniae is usually not seen on Gram stain because it lacks a bacterial cell wall; the microscopy findings characteristic of Chlamydia pneumoniae infection are intracellular inclusions.
questions.hint: This immunocompromised patient presents with signs and symptoms of infection in multiple locations: lungs (hemoptysis, consolidated lung mass on x-ray), skin (ulceration), and CNS (seizure, brain abscess on MRI). The presence of weakly acid-fast, branching bacteria confirms the diagnosis of disseminated nocardiosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of fatigue, low-grade fevers, and cough productive of blood-tinged sputum. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease and underwent kidney transplantation 8 months ago. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.1°F) and pulse is 98/min. Examination shows rhonchi in the right lower lung field. An x-ray of the chest shows a right-sided lobar consolidation. A photomicrograph of specialized acid-fast stained tissue from a blood culture is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Poor oral hygiene is a predisposing factor for infection with Actinomyces spp., which is also a gram-positive, branching, rod-shaped bacteria. Thoracic actinomycosis can manifest with a cough and hemoptysis, similar to this patient. However, Actinomyces are nonacid fast, anaerobic bacteria, and infection does not usually cause lobar pneumonia.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with signs and symptoms of pulmonary nocardiosis. Nocardia is a weakly acid-fast, catalase-positive bacterium that forms branching filaments and is ubiquitous in soil worldwide. Risk factors for Nocardia infection include immune suppression (e.g., HIV, organ transplant, glucocorticoid use), diabetes, alcohol use disorder, and chronic granulomatous disease. A suspected diagnosis is confirmed via culture from infected material (e.g., sputum).

C) INCORRECT:

Warm aqueous environments such as air conditioning units can be a habitat for Legionella pneumophila. Infection with L. pneumophila can cause Legionnaires' disease (especially in immunocompromised individuals) and present with atypical or lobar pneumonia. However, this patient lacks other classic features of Legionnaires' disease such as gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea). Moreover, L. pneumophila does not stain with acid-fast staining and would require silver staining for detection.

D) INCORRECT:

Sharing of unsterile IV needles (e.g., IV drug use) is a risk factor for blood-borne infections including hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and HIV infection. However, none of these pathogens would explain the photomicrograph findings seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Congregate settings (e.g., hospitals, homeless shelters) can be a predisposing factor for several infections, including Mycobacterium tuberculosis, which also appears as gram-positive, acid-fast bacteria on light microscopy. Although tuberculosis classically presents with pulmonary symptoms such as productive cough and hemoptysis, chest x-ray would typically show upper lobe cavitary lung lesions, rather than lobar pneumonia. The presence of branching filaments on this patient's culture is also not consistent with a diagnosis of tuberculosis.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows partially acid-fast, branching rods characteristic of Nocardia species.

questions.text: A medical technician is trying to isolate a pathogen from the sputum sample of a patient. The sample is heat fixed to a slide then covered with carbol fuchsin stain and heated again. After washing off the stain with clean water, the slide is covered with sulfuric acid. The sample is rinsed again and stained with methylene blue. Microscopic examination shows numerous red organisms. Which of the following is the most likely isolated pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tropheryma whipplei can be identified using periodic acid-Schiff staining, not carbol fuchsin. Periodic acid-Schiff stains glycogen and mucopolysaccharides blue, and it can be used to detect PAS-positive macrophages in the diagnosis of Whipple disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Rickettsia rickettsii can be identified using Giemsa staining, not carbol fuchsin. Other pathogens that can be identified using Giemsa staining include Borrelia, Chlamydia, and Plasmodia.

C) CORRECT:

Nocardia asteroides is a weakly acid-fast organism that partially retains carbol fuchsin stain after it is rinsed with sulfuric acid. Other important acid-fast organisms that stain positive with Ziehl-Neelsen staining include mycobacteria (e.g., M. tuberculosis) and the oocysts of Cryptosporidium and Isospora. Acid-fast bacteria can also be identified using Kinyoun stain.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Ziehl-Neelsen stain; 1000× magnification)

The curved, rod-shaped bacteria appear bright red after staining.

D) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans can be identified using India ink staining, mucicarmine staining, or silver staining, but not carbol fuchsin. The polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans appears as a halo around the organism when India ink staining is applied. When mucicarmine staining is used, the polysaccharide capsule appears red.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a fungal culture (India ink stain)

Numerous spherical yeast cells of different sizes can be seen. The polysaccharide capsules appear as yellowish halos around the cell walls (dark circles).

These features are characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans under light microscopy.

E) INCORRECT:

Helicobacter pylori can be identified using Giemsa staining or silver staining, but not carbol fuchsin. Other pathogens that can be identified using silver staining include Legionella, Pseudomonas, and Pneumocystis jirovecii.

F) INCORRECT:

Trypanosoma cruzi can be identified using Giemsa staining, not carbol fuchsin. Other pathogens that can be identified using Giemsa staining include Borrelia, Chlamydia, and Plasmodia.
Image Description:

Blood smear (Giemsa stain, 100x magnification)

The parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, can be seen in the center of this blood smear (green overlay). Its characteristic flagellum (yellow overlay) is clearly recognizable.

G) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus can be identified using Gram staining, in which crystal violet dye is first applied to the specimen, followed by a safranin counterstain. Although carbol fuchsin can be used as a counterstain, safranin is much more commonly used. Furthermore, no crystal violet dyes were used on the sample.
questions.hint: The procedure (Ziehl-Neelsen staining) described is used to identify organisms with mycolic acid in their cell walls.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman who underwent renal transplantation 3 years ago for focal segmental glomerulosclerosis reports having an intermittent cough and low-grade fevers for the past 2 months. Her immunosuppressive therapy consists of prednisone 10 mg daily and tacrolimus 2.5 mg twice daily.
Pulmonary examination is unremarkable. However, a chest radiograph reveals small, nodular densities in the right upper and lower lung fields. The patient subsequently undergoes bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage. Initial cultures show no growth but, 8 weeks after inoculation, reveal gram-positive, weakly acid-fast-positive filamentous organisms.
Which one of the following signs is most likely to develop if the patient remains untreated?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nocardia is not associated with hemolysis and very rarely affects the liver, making icterus highly unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Nocardiosis refers to invasive disease caused by members of the genus Nocardia. Nocardia species are filamentous, aerobic, nonspore-forming saprophytic organisms found naturally in soil. Nocardia infection typically affects immunocompromised hosts.

Respiratory tract disease is the most common clinical manifestation, but extrapulmonary dissemination occurs in about half of patients with known pulmonary nocardiosis. Although the organism can affect any organ system, the most common site of dissemination is the central nervous system, followed by skin, bone, and muscle.

Key learning point: The most common extrapulmonary site of disseminated nocardiosis is the central nervous system.

C) INCORRECT:

Nocardia species rarely cause endocarditis (which could result in a cardiac murmur and lead to retinal hemorrhages and splenomegaly). However, cardiac involvement is quite atypical and much less likely to occur than dissemination to the central nervous system, skin, and soft tissues.

D) INCORRECT:

Nocardia species rarely cause endocarditis (which could result in a cardiac murmur and lead to retinal hemorrhages and splenomegaly). However, cardiac involvement is quite atypical and much less likely to occur than dissemination to the central nervous system, skin, and soft tissues.

E) INCORRECT:

Pericarditis can occur through direct inoculation from the lungs, and Nocardia species rarely cause endocarditis (which could result in a cardiac murmur and lead to retinal hemorrhages and splenomegaly). However, cardiac involvement is quite atypical and much less likely to occur than dissemination to the central nervous system, skin, and soft tissues.
